subsection.title: Order of Operations
subsection.p: Numerical calculations often involve more than one operation. So that everyone agrees on how such expressions should be evaluated, we follow the order of operations.

li.p: Simplify any expressions within grouping symbols (parentheses, brackets, square root bars, or fraction bars). Start with the innermost grouping symbols and work outward.
Evaluate all powers and roots.
Perform multiplications and divisions in order from left to right.
Perform additions and subtractions in order from left to right.

subsection.title: Parentheses and Fraction Bars
subsection.p:
We can use parentheses to override the multiplication-first rule. Compare the two expressions below.
\amp\text{The sum of 4 times 6 and 10} \amp\amp 4 \cdot 6 + 10 \amp\text{4 times the sum of 6 and 10} \amp\amp 4(6 + 10)
In the first expression, we perform the multiplication 4\times 6 first, but in the second expression we perform the addition 6 + 10 first, because it is enclosed in parentheses.
The location (or absence) of parentheses can drastically alter the meaning of an expression. In the following example, note how the location of the parentheses changes the value of the expression.

warning.p: In the expression 5 - 12^2, which appears in , the exponent 2 applies only to 12, not to -12. Thus, 5 - 12^2 \ne 5 + 144.

subsection.p: The order of operations mentions other grouping devices besides parentheses: fraction bars and square root bars. Notice how the placement of the fraction bar affects the expressions in the next example.

subsection.title: Radicals
subsection.p: You are already familiar with square roots. Every nonnegative number has two square roots, defined as follows: s ~~\text{ is a square root of }~~ n ~~\text{ if }~~s^2 = n There are several other kinds of roots, one of which is called the cube rootcube root, denoted by \sqrt[3]{n}. We define the cube root as follows.

assemblage.title: Cube Roots
assemblage.p: b ~~\text{ is a cube root of }~~~ n ~~~\text{ if }~~~ b ~\text{ cubed equals }~~n. In symbols, we write b=\sqrt[3]{n} ~~\text{ if } ~~ b^3=n

subsection.p: Although we cannot take the square root of a negative number, we can take the cube root of any real number. For example, \sqrt[3]{64}=4 ~~\text{ because }~~ 4^3=64 and \sqrt[3]{-27}=-3 ~~\text{ because }~~ (-3)^3=-27
In the order of operations, simplifying radicals and powers comes after parentheses but before products and quotients.

subsection.title: Scientific Notation
subsection.p: Scientists and engineers regularly encounter very large numbers such as 5,980,000,000,000,000,000,000,000 (the mass of the Earth in kilograms) and very small numbers such as 0.000 \,000 \,000 \,000 \,000 \,000 \,000 \,001 \,67 (the mass of a hydrogen atom in grams). These numbers can be written in a more compact and useful form by using powers of 10.

In our base 10 number system, multiplying a number by a positive power of 10 has the effect of moving the decimal place k places to the right, where k is the exponent in the power of 10. For example, 3.529 \times 10^2 = 352.9 ~~~\text{ and }~~~ 25 \times 104 = 250,000 Multiplying by a power of 10 with a negative exponent moves the decimal place to the left. For example, 1728 \times 10^{-3} = 1.728 ~~~\text{ and }~~~ 4.6 \times 10^{-5} = 0.000046

assemblage.title: To Write a Number in Scientific Notation:

li.p: Locate the decimal point so that there is exactly one nonzero digit to its left.

Count the number of places you moved the decimal point: This determines the power of 10.
If the original number is greater than 10, the exponent is positive.
If the original number is less than 1, the exponent is negative.

example.p: The average American eats 110 kilograms of meat per year. It takes about 16 kilograms of grain to produce 1 kilogram of meat, and advanced farming techniques can produce about 6000 kilograms of grain on each hectare of arable land. (The hectare is 10,000 square meters, or just under 2 1⁄2 acres.) Now, the total land area of the Earth is about 13 billion hectares, but only about 11\% of that land is arable. Is it possible for each of the 5.5 billion people on Earth to eat as much meat as Americans do?

introduction.p: An equation is just a mathematical statement that two expressions are equal. Equations relating two variables are particularly useful. If we know the value of one of the variables, we can find the corresponding value of the other variable by solving the equation.

example.p: The equation w = 6h gives Loren's wages, w, in terms of the number of hours she works, h. How many hours does Loren need to work next week if she wants to earn \$225?

solution.p:
We know that w = 225, and we would like to know the value of h. We substitute the value for w into our equation and then solve for h.
w \amp= 6h\amp\amp \text{Substitute 225 for }w. \alert{225} \amp= 6h\amp\amp \text{Divide both sides by } 6. \frac{225}{\alert{6}}\amp = \frac{6h}{\alert{6}}\amp\amp \text{Simplify.} 375.5\amp = h
Loren must work 37.5 hours in order to earn \$225. In reality, Loren will probably have to work for 38 hours, because most employers do not pay for portions of an hour's work. Thus, Loren needs to work for 38 hours.

introduction.p: To solve an equation we can generate simpler equations that have the same solutions. Equations that have identical solutions are called equivalent equationsequivalent equations. For example, 3x - 5 = x + 3 and 2x = 8 are equivalent equations because the solution of each equation is 4. Often we can find simpler equivalent equations by undoing in reverse order the operations performed on the variable.

subsection.title: Solving Linear Equations
subsection.p: Linear, or first-degree, equations can be written so that every term is either a constant or a constant times the variable. The equations above are examples of linear equations. Recall the following rules for solving linear equations.

li.p: We can add or subtract the same number on both sides of an equation.
We can multiply or divide both sides of an equation by the same number (except zero).

subsection.p: Applying either of these rules produces a new equation equivalent to the old one and thus preserves the solution.We use the rules to isolate the variable on one side of the equation.

example.p: Solve the equation 3x - 5 = x + 3.

subsection.p: The following steps should enable you to solve any linear equation. Of course, you may not need all the steps for a particular equation.

li.p:
Simplify each side of the equation separately.
Apply the distributive law to remove parentheses.
Collect like terms.
By adding or subtracting appropriate terms to both sides of the equation, get all the variable terms on one side and all the constant terms on the other.
Divide both sides of the equation by the coefficient of the variable.

solution.p:
We begin by simplifying each side of the equation.
3(2x - 5) - 4x \amp = 2x - (6 - 3x) \amp\amp\text{Apply the distributive law.}
6x - 15 - 4x \amp= 2x - 6 + 3x \amp\amp\text{Combine like terms on each side.}
2x - 15 \amp= 5x - 6
Next, we collect all the variable terms on the left side of the equation, and all the constant terms on the right side.
2x - 15 - 5x + 15 \amp= 5x - 6 - 5x + 15 \amp\amp\text{Add }-5x + 15 \text{ to both sides.}
-3x \amp= 9
Finally, we divide both sides of the equation by the coefficient of the variable.
-3x \amp= 9 \amp\amp\text{Divide both sides by }-3.
x \amp =-3
The solution is -3.

subsection.title: Formulas
subsection.p: A formulaformula is an equation that relates several variables. For example, the equation P = 2l + 2w gives the perimeter of a rectangle in terms of its length and width.

example.p: The formula 5F = 9C + 160 relates the temperature in degrees Fahrenheit, F, to the temperature in degrees Celsius, C. Solve the formula for C in terms of F.
Solve 3x - 5y = 40 for y in terms of x.

subsection.title: Linear Inequalities
subsection.p: Inequalities that include the symbols \gt or \le are called strict inequalitiesstrict inequalities; those that include \ge or \le are called nonstrictnonstrict.

If we multiply or divide both sides of an inequality by a negative number, the direction of the inequality must be reversed. For example, if we multiply both sides of the inequality 2\lt 5 by -3, we get
\alert{-3}(2) \amp\gt \alert{-3}(5)\amp\amp \text{Change inequality symbol from }\lt \text{ to }\gt. -6 \amp\gt -15.
Because of this property, the rules for solving linear equations must be revised slightly for solving linear inequalities.

li.p: We may add or subtract the same number to both sides of an inequality without changing its solutions.
We may multiply or divide both sides of an inequality by a positive number without changing its solutions.
If we multiply or divide both sides of an inequality by a negative number, we must reverse the direction of the inequality symbol.

example.p: Solve the inequality 4 - 3x \ge -17.

solution.p:
Use the rules above to isolate x on one side of the inequality.
4 - 3x \amp\ge -17\amp\amp\text{Subtract 4 from both sides.}
-3x \amp\ge -21\amp\amp\text{Divide both sides by }-3.
x \amp\le 7
Notice that we reversed the direction of the inequality when we divided by -3. Any number less than or equal to 7 is a solution of the inequality.

subsection.p: A compound inequalitycompound inequality involves two inequality symbols.

example.p: Solve 4 \le 3x + 10 \le 16.

solution.p:
We isolate x by performing the same operations on all three sides of the inequality.
4 \amp{}\le{} 3x\amp {}+{}\amp 10 \amp{}\le{} 16\hphantom{blank} \amp\text{Subtract }10.
-6 \amp{}\le{} \amp 3x\amp {}{}\amp {}\le{} 6\hphantom{blank} \amp\text{Divide by }3.
-2 \amp{}\le{} \amp x\amp {}{}\amp{}\le{} 2\hphantom{blank}\amp
The solutions are all numbers between -2 and 2, inclusive.

subsection.title: Interval Notation
subsection.p: The solutions of the inequality in form an interval. An intervalinterval is a set that consists of all the real numbers between two numbers a and b.

The set -2 \le x \le 2 includes its endpoints -2 and 2, so we call it a closed intervalclosed interval, and we denote it by [-2, 2] (see a). The square brackets tell us that the endpoints are included in the interval. An interval that does not include its endpoints, such as -2 \lt x \lt 2, is called an open intervalopen interval, and we denote it with round brackets, (-2, 2) (see b). closed interval and open interva

warning.p: Do not confuse the open interval (-2, 2) with the point (-2, 2)! The notation is the same, so you must decide from the context whether an interval or a point is being discussed.

subsection.p: We can also discuss infinite intervalsinfinite intervals, such as x\lt 3 and x\ge -1, shown in . We denote the interval x\lt 3 by (-\infty, 3), and the interval x\ge -1 by [-1, \infty). The symbol \infty, for infinity, does not represent a specific real number; it indicates that the interval continues forever along the real line. infinite intervals

Finally, we can combine two or more intervals into a larger set. For example, the set consisting of x\lt -1 or x\gt 2, shown in , is the unionunion of two intervals and is denoted by (-\infty,-2) \cup (2,\infty). number line with two disjoint infinite intervals
Many solutions of inequalities are intervals or unions of intervals.

introduction.p: You are familiar with the use of letters, or variables, to stand for unknown numbers in equations or formulas. Variables are also used to represent numerical quantities that change over time or in different situations. For example, p might stand for the atmospheric pressure at different heights above the Earth's surface. Or N might represent the number of people infected with cholera t days after the start of an epidemic.

An algebraic expressionalgebraic expression is any meaningful combination of numbers, variables, and symbols of operation. Algebraic expressions are used to express relationships between variable quantities.

example.p:
Loren makes \$6 an hour working at the campus bookstore.
Choose a variable for the number of hours Loren works per week.
Write an algebraic expression for the amount of Loren's weekly earnings.

li.p: Let h stand for the number of hours Loren works per week.
The amount Loren earns is given by 6\times (\text{number of hours Loren worked}) or 6\cdot h. Loren's weekly earnings can be expressed as 6h.

introduction.p: The algebraic expression 6h represents the amount of money Loren earns in terms of the number of hours she works. If we substitute a specific value for the variable in an expression, we find a numerical value for the expression. This is called evaluatingevaluating the expression.

example.p: If Loren from works for 16 hours in the bookstore this week, how much will she earn?

solution.p:
Evaluate the expression 6h for h=\alert{16}.
6h = 6(\alert{16}) = 96
Loren will make \$96.

example.p:
April sells environmentally friendly cleaning products. Her income consists of \$200 per week plus a commission of 9\% of her sales.
Choose variables to represent the unknown quantities and write an algebraic expression for April's weekly income in terms of her sales.
Find April's income for a week in which she sells \$350 worth of cleaning products.

li.p:
Let I represent April's total income for the week, and let S represent the total amount of her sales. We translate the information from the problem into mathematical language as follows:
\text{Her income consists of }\$200 . . .\text{ plus }. . . 9\% \text{ of her sales}
I \hphantom{consists of}= \hphantom{of}200 \hphantom{plus+}+ \hphantom{....}0.09 \hphantom{of her}S
Thus, I = 200 + 0.09S.

We want to evaluate our expression from part (a) with S = 350. We substitute \alert{350} for S to find I = 200 + 0.09(\alert{350}) Following the order of operations, we perform the multiplication before the addition. Thus, we begin by computing 0.09(350).
I \amp = 200 + 0.09(350)\amp\amp\text{Multiply }0.09 (350) \text{ first.}
\amp = 200 + 31.5 \amp = 231.50
April's income for the week is \$231.50.

remark.title: Calculator Tip

example.p:
Economy Parcel Service charges \$2.80 per pound to deliver a package from Pasadena to Cedar Rapids. Andrew wants to mail a painting that weighs 8.3 pounds, plus whatever packing material he uses.
Choose variables to represent the unknown quantities and write an expression for the cost of shipping Andrew's painting.
Find the shipping cost if Andrew uses 2.9 pounds of packing material.

li.p: Let C stand for the shipping cost and let w stand for the weight of the packing material. Andrew must find the total weight of his package first, then multiply by the shipping charge. The total weight of the package is 8.3 + w pounds. We use parentheses around this expression to show that it should be computed first, and the sum should be multiplied by the shipping charge of \$2.80 per pound. Thus, C = 2.80(8.3 + w)

remark.title: Calculator Tip

warning.p: If we omit the parentheses, the calculator will perform the multiplication before the addition. Thus, the keying sequence 2.80 \times 8.3 + 2.9 gives an incorrect result for . (The sequence 8.3 + 2.9 \times 2.80 does not work either!)

subsection.title: Problem Solving
subsection.p: Problem solving often involves translating a real-life problem into a computer programming language, or, in our case, into algebraic expressions. We can then use algebra to solve the mathematical problem and interpret the solution in the context of the original problem. Here are some guidelines for problem solving with algebraic equations.

li.p: Identify the unknown quantity and assign a variable to represent it.
Find some quantity that can be expressed in two different ways and write an equation.
Solve the equation.
Interpret your solution to answer the question in the problem.

subsection.p: In step 1, begin by writing an English phrase to describe the quantity you are looking for. Be as specific as possible—if you are going to write an equation about this quantity, you must understand its properties! Remember that your variable must represent a numerical quantity. For example, x can represent the speed of a train, but not just “the train.”

Writing an equation is the hardest part of the problem. Note that the quantity mentioned in step 2 will probably not be the same unknown quantity you are looking for, but the algebraic expressions you write will involve your variable. For example, if your variable represents the speed of a train, your equation might be about the distance the train traveled.

subsection.title: Supply and Demand
subsection.p: The law of supply and demand is fundamental in economics. If you increase the price of a product, the supply increases because its manufacturers are willing to provide more of the product, but the demand decreases because consumers are not willing to buy as much at a higher price. The price at which the demand for a product equals the supply is called the equilibrium priceequilibrium price.

example.p: The Coffee Connection finds that when it charges p dollars for a pound of coffee, it can sell 800 - 60p pounds per month. On the other hand, at a price of p dollars a pound, International Food and Beverage will supply the Connection with 175 + 40p pounds of coffee per month. What price should the Coffee Connection charge for a pound of coffee so that its monthly inventory will sell out?

li.p: We are looking for the equilibrium price, p.
The Coffee Connection would like the demand for its coffee to equal its supply. We equate the expressions for supply and for demand to obtain the equation 800 - 60p = 175 + 40p

Solve the equation. To get all terms containing the variable, p, on one side of the equation, we add 60p to both sides and subtract 175 from both sides to obtain
800 - 60p + \alert{60p - 175} \amp= 175 + 40p + \alert{60p - 175}
625 \amp = 100p \amp\amp\text{Divide both sides by }100.
6.25 \amp = p
The Coffee Connection should charge \$6.25 per pound for its coffee.

subsection.title: Percent Problems
subsection.p: Recall the basic formula for computing percents.

assemblage.title: Percent Formula
assemblage.p: P = rW the Part (or percent) = the percentage rate \times the Whole Amount

subsection.p:
A percent increasepercent increase or percent decreasepercent decrease is calculated as a fraction of the original amount. For example, suppose you make \$16.00 an hour now, but next month you are expecting a 5\% raise. Your new salary should be
\stackrel{\text{Original salary}}{\$16.00} + \stackrel{\text{Increase}}{0.05(\$16.00)} = \stackrel{\text{New Salary}}{\$16.80}

example.p: The price of housing in urban areas increased 4\% over the past year. If a certain house costs \$100,000 today, what was its price last year?

li.p: Let c represent the cost of the house last year.

Express the current price of the house in two different ways. During the past year, the price of the house increased by 4\%, or 0.04c. Its current price is thus \stackrel{\text{Original cost}}{(1)c} + \stackrel{\text{Price increase}}{0.04c} = c(1 + 0.04) = 1.04c This expression is equal to the value given for current price of the house: 1.04c = 100,000
To solve this equation, we divide both sides by 1.04 to find c = \frac{100,000}{1.04}= 96,153.846
To the nearest cent, the cost of the house last year was \$96,153.85.

warning.p: In , it would be incorrect to calculate last year's price by subtracting 4\% of \$100,000 from \$100,000 to get \$96,000. (Do you see why?)

subsection.title: Weighted Averages

example.p: Kwan's grade in his accounting class will be computed as follows: Tests count for 50\% of the grade, homework counts for 20\%, and the final exam counts for 30\%. If Kwan has an average of 84 on tests and 92 on homework, what score does he need on the final exam to earn a grade of 90?

li.p: Let x represent the final exam score Kwan needs.

Kwan's grade is the weighted average of his test, homework, and final exam scores. \frac{\alert{0.50}(84) + \alert{0.20}(92) + \alert{0.30}x}{1.00}=90 (The sum of the weights is 1.00, or 100% of Kwan’s grade.) Multiply both sides of the equation by 1.00 to get 0.50(84) + 0.20(92) + 0.30x = 1.00(90)
Kwan needs a score of 98.7 on the final exam to earn a grade of 90.

subsection.p: In step 2 of , we rewrote the formula for a weighted average in a simpler form.

assemblage.title: Weighted Average

subsection.p: This form is particularly useful for solving problems involving mixtures.

example.p: The vet advised Delbert to feed his dog Rollo with kibble that is no more than 8\% fat. Rollo likes JuicyBits, which are 15\% fat. LeanMeal is more expensive, but it is only 5\% fat. How much LeanMeal should Delbert mix with 50 pounds of JuicyBits to make amixture that is 8\% fat?

li.p: Let p represent the number of pounds of LeanMeal needed.

In this problem, we want the weighted average of the fat contents in the two kibbles to be 8\%. The weights are the number of pounds of each kibble we use. It is often useful to summarize the given information in a table.

\% fat Total pounds Pounds of fat
Juicy Bits 15\% 50 0.15(50)
LeanMeal 5\% p 0.05p
Mixture 8\% 50+p 0.08(50+p)
The amount of fat in the mixture must come from adding the amounts of fat in the two ingredients. This gives us an equation, 0.15(50) + 0.05p = 0.08(50 + p) This equation is an example of the formula for weighted averages.

Simplify each side of the equation, then solve.
7.5 + 0.05p \amp = 4 + 0.08p
3.5 \amp = 0.03p
p \amp = 116.\overline{6}
Delbert should mix 116\frac{2}{3} pounds of LeanMeal with 50 pounds of JuicyBits to make a mixture that is 8\% fat.

introduction.p: Graphs are useful tools for studying mathematical relationships. A graph provides an overview of a quantity of data, and it helps us identify trends or unexpected occurrences. Interpreting the graph can help us answer questions about the data.
For example, here are some data showing the atmospheric pressure at different altitudes. Altitude is given in feet, and atmospheric pressure is given in inches of mercury.

We observe a generally decreasing trend in pressure as the altitude increases, but it is difficult to say anything more precise about this relationship. A clearer picture emerges if we plot the data. To do this, we use two perpendicular number lines called axes. We use the horizontal axis for the values of the first variable, altitude, and the vertical axis for the values of the second variable, pressure.

The entries in the table are called ordered pairs, in which the first component is the altitude and the second component is the atmospheric pressure measured at that altitude. For example, the first two entries can be represented by (0, 29.7) and (5000, 24.8). We plot the points whose coordinates are given by the ordered pairs, as shown in a. graphs of pressure vs altitude

We can connect the data points with a smooth curve as shown in b. In doing this, we are assuming that one variable changes smoothly with respect to the other, and in fact this is true for many physical situations. Thus, a smooth curve will thus serve as a good model.

subsection.title: Reading a Graph
subsection.p: Once we have constructed a graph, we can use it to estimate values of the variables between the known data points.

example.p:
From the graph in b, estimate the following:
The atmospheric pressure measured at an altitude of 15,000 feet
The altitude at which the pressure is 12 inches of mercury

li.p: The point with first coordinate 15,000 on the graph in has second coordinate approximately 17.4. We estimate the pressure at 15,000 feet to be 17.4 inches of mercury. graph of pressure vs altitude with two points highlighted
The point on the graph with second coordinate 12 has first coordinate approximately 25,000, so an atmospheric pressure of 12 inches of mercury occurs at about 25,000 feet.

subsection.p: We can also use the graph to obtain information about the relationship between altitude and pressure that would be difficult to see from the data alone.

li.p: For what altitudes is the pressure less than 18 inches of mercury?
How much does the pressure decrease as the altitude increases from 15,000 feet to 25,000 feet?
For which 10,000-foot increase in altitude does the pressure change most rapidly?

From the graph in b, we see that the pressure has dropped to 18 inches of mercury at about 14,000 feet, and that it continues to decrease as the altitude increases. Therefore, the pressure is less than 18 inches of mercury for altitudes greater than 14,000 feet.
The pressure at 15,000 feet is approximately 17.4 inches of mercury, and at 25,000 feet it is 12 inches. This represents a decrease in pressure of 17.4 - 12, or 5.4, inches of mercury.
By studying the graph we see that the pressure decreases most rapidly at low altitudes, so we conclude that the greatest drop in pressure occurs between 0 and 10,000 feet.

subsection.title: Graphs of Equations
subsection.p: In , we used a graph to illustrate data given in a table. Graphs can also help us analyze models given by equations. Let us first review some facts about solutions of equations in two variables.

An equation in two variables, such as y = 2x + 3, is said to be satisfied if the variables are replaced by a pair of numbers that make the statement true. The pair of numbers is called a solutionsolution of the equation and is usually written as an ordered pair (x, y). (The first number in the pair is the value of x and the second number is the value of y.)
To find a solution of a given equation, we can assign a number to one of the variables and then solve for the second variable.

example.p: Find solutions to the equation y = 2x + 3.

solution.p:
We choose some values for x, say, -2, 0, and 1. Substitute these x-values into the equation to find a corresponding y-value for each.
\amp\text{When }x=-2,\amp\amp y = 2(\alert{-2}) + 3 =-1
\amp\text{When }x=0,\amp\amp y = 2(\alert{0}) + 3 =3
\amp\text{When }x=1,\amp\amp y = 2(\alert{1}) + 3 =5
Thus, the ordered pairs (-2, -1), (0, 3), and (1, 5) are three solutions of y = 2x + 3. We can also substitute values for y. For example, if we let y = \alert{10}, we have \alert{10} = 2x + 3 Solving this equation for x, we find 7 = 2x, or x = 3.5. This means that the ordered pair (3.5, 10) is another solution of the equation y = 2x + 3.

subsection.p: An equation in two variables may have infinitely many solutions, so we cannot list them all. However, we can display the solutions on a graph. For this we use a CartesianCartesian (or rectangularrectangular) coordinate systemcoordinate system, as shown in .

The graph of an equationgraph of an equation is a picture of its solutions. A point is included in the graph if its coordinates satisfy the equation, and if the coordinates do not satisfy the equation, the point is not part of the graph. A graph of y = 2x + 3 is shown in .

This graph does not display all the solutions of the equation, but it shows important features such as the intercepts on the x- and y-axes. Because there is a solution corresponding to every real number x, the graph extends infinitely in either direction, as indicated by the arrows.

introduction.p: A 2\times 2 system of equations is a set of 2 equations in the same 2 variables. A solutionsolution of a 2\times 2 system is an ordered pair that makes each equation in the system true. In this section, we review two algebraic methods for solving 2\times 2 linear systems: substitution and elimination.

subsection.title: Solving Systems by Substitution
subsection.p: The basic strategy for the substitutionsubstitution method can be described as follows.

assemblage.title: Steps for Solving a 2\tines 2 System by Substitution

li.p: Solve one of the equations for one of the variables in terms of the other.
Substitute this expression into the second equation; doing so yields an equation in one variable.
Solve the new equation.
Use the result of step 1 to find the other variable.

example.p: Staci stocks two kinds of sleeping bags in her sporting goods store, a standard model and a down-filled model for colder temperatures. From past experience, she estimates that she will sell twice as many of the standard variety as of the down filled. She has room to stock 60 sleeping bags at a time. How many of each variety should Staci order?

li.p: Write two equations about the variables. Staci needs twice as many standard model as down filled, so x \amp = 2y\amp\amp\hphantom{blankety}(1) Also, the total number of sleeping bags is 60, so x+y \amp = 60\amp\amp\hphantom{blank}(2)

We will solve this system using substitution. Notice that Equation (1) is already solved for x in terms of y: x = 2y. Substitute \alert{2y} for x in Equation (2) to obtain
\alert{2y} + y \amp = 60
3y\amp = 60
Solving for y, we find y=\alert{20}. Finally, substitute this value into Equation (1) to find x = 2(\alert{20}) = 40 The solution to the system is x = 40, y = 20.
Staci should order 40 standard sleeping bags and 20 down-filled bags.

subsection.title: Solving Systems by Elimination
subsection.p: The method of substitution is convenient if one of the variables in the system has a coefficient of 1 or -1, because it is easy to solve for that variable. If none of the coefficients is 1 or -1s, then a second method, called eliminationelimination, is usually more efficient.
The method of elimination is based on the following properties of linear equations.

li.p: Multiplying a linear equation by a (nonzero) constant does not change its solutions. That is, any solution of the equation ax + by = c is also a solution of the equation kax + kby = kc

Adding (or subtracting) two linear equations does not change their common solutions. That is, any solution of the system
a_1x + b_1 y \amp = c_1 a_2x + b_2 y \amp = c_2
is also a solution of the equation (a_1 + a_2) x + (b_1 + b_2) y = c_1 + c_2

example.p:
Solve the system by the method of elimination.
2x\amp {}+{}\amp 3y\amp ={}\amp 8 \hphantom{blankblank}\amp(1) 3x\amp {}-{}\amp 4y\amp ={}\amp -5 \hphantom{blankblank}\amp(2)

solution.p:
We first decide which variable to eliminate, x or y. We can choose whichever looks easiest. In this problem, we choose to eliminate x. We next look for the smallest number that both coefficients, 2 and 3, divide into evenly. This number is 6. We want the coefficients of x to become 6 and -6, so we will multiply Equation (1) by 3 and Equation (2) by -2 to obtain
6x\amp {}+{}\amp 9y\amp ={}\amp 24 \hphantom{blankblank}\amp(1\text{a}) -6x\amp {}+{}\amp 8y\amp ={}\amp 10 \hphantom{blankblank}\amp(2\text{a})
Now add the corresponding terms of (1a) and (2a). The x-terms are eliminated, yielding an equation in one variable.
6x\amp {}+{}\amp 9y\amp ={}\amp 24 \hphantom{blankblank}\amp(1\text{a}) -6x\amp {}+{}\amp 8y\amp ={}\amp 10 \hphantom{blankblank}\amp(2\text{a}) {}\amp {}{}\amp 17y\amp ={}\amp 34 \hphantom{blankblank}\amp(3)
Solve this equation for y to find y=\alert{2}. We can substitute this value of y into any of our equations involving both x and y. If we choose Equation (1), then 2x + 3 (\alert{2}) = 8 and solving this equation yields x=1. The ordered pair (1, 2) is a solution to the system. You should verify that these values satisfy both original equations.

subsection.p: We summarize the strategy for solving a linear system by elimination.

assemblage.title: Steps for Solving a 2\times 2 Linear System by Elimination

li.p: Choose one of the variables to eliminate. Multiply each equation by a suitable factor so that the coefficients of that variable are opposites.
Add the two new equations termwise.
Solve the resulting equation for the remaining variable.
Substitute the value found in step 3 into either of the original equations and solve for the other variable.

subsection.p: In , we added 3 times the first equation to -2 times the second equation. The result from adding a constant multiple of one equation to a constant multiple of another equation is called a linear combinationlinear combination of the two equations. The method of elimination is also called the method of linear combinationslinear combinations.
If either equation in a system has fractional coefficients, it is helpful to clear the fractions before applying the method of linear combinations.

example.p:
Solve the system by linear combinations.
\frac{2}{3}x\amp {}-{}\amp y\amp ={}\amp 2 \hphantom{blankblank}\amp(1) x\amp {}+{}\amp \frac{1}{2}y\amp ={}\amp 7 \hphantom{blankblank}\amp(2)

solution.p:
Multiply each side of Equation (1) by 3 and each side of Equation (2) by 2 to clear the fractions:
2x\amp {}-{}\amp 3y\amp ={}\amp 6 \hphantom{blankblank}\amp(1\text{a}) 2x\amp {}+{}\amp y\amp ={}\amp 14 \hphantom{blankblank}\amp(2\text{a})
To eliminate the variable x, multiply Equation (2a) by -1 and add the result to Equation (1a) to get
-4y \amp = -8 \amp\amp\text{Divide both sides by -4.} y \amp = 2
Substitute \alert{2} for y in one of the original equations and solve for x. We use Equation (2).
x + \frac{1}{2}(\alert{2}) \amp = 7 \amp\amp\text{Subtract 1 from both sides.} x \amp = 6
Verify that x=6 and y=2 satisfy both Equations (1) and (2). The solution to the system is the ordered pair (6, 2).

introduction.p: In this section, we review the rules for performing operations on powers.

subsection.title: Product of Powers
subsection.p: Consider a product of two powers with the same base. (a^3) (a^2) = a a a \cdot a a = a^5 because a occurs as a factor five times. The number of a's in the product is the sum of the number of a's in each factor.

assemblage.title: First Law of Exponents: Product of Powers
assemblage.p: To multiply two powers with the same base, add the exponents and leave the base unchanged. a^m \cdot a^n = a^{m+n}

image.description: figure showing that when powers of the same base are multiplied that base is retained with exponent equal to the sum of the original exponents

subsection.p: Here are some mistakes to avoid.

li.p: Note that we do not multiply the exponents when simplifying a product. For example, b^4 \cdot b^2 \ne b^8 You can check this with your calculator by choosing a value for b, for instance, b = 3: 3^4 \cdot 3^2\ne 3^8
In order to apply the first law of exponents, the bases must be the same. For example, 2^3 \cdot 3^5 \ne 6^8 (Check this on your calculator.)
We do not multiply the bases when simplifying a product. In a, note that 5^3 \cdot 5^4\ne 25^7
Although we can simplify the product x^2x^3 as x^5, we cannot simplify the sum x^2 + x^3, because x^2 and x^3 are not like terms.

example.p: Multiply (-3x^4z^2) (5x^3 z).

solution.p:
Rearrange the factors to group the numerical coefficients and the powers of each base. Apply the first law of exponents.
(-3x^4z^2) (5x^3z) \amp = (-3) (5)x^4x^3z^2z \amp = -15x^7z^3

subsection.title: Quotients of Powers
subsection.p:
To reduce a fraction, we divide both numerator and denominator by any common factors.
\require{cancel} \require{color} \renewcommand{\CancelColor}{\blue} \frac{x^7}{x^4}=\frac{xxx\cancel{x}\cancel{x}\cancel{x}\cancel{x}}{\cancel{x}\cancel{x}\cancel{x}\cancel{x}}=\frac{x^3}{1}=x^3
We can obtain the same result more quickly by subtracting the exponent of the denominator from the exponent of the numerator. \frac{x^7}{x^4}=x^{7-4}=x^3

assemblage.title: Second Law of Exponents: Quotient of Powers
assemblage.p:
To divide two powers with the same base, subtract the smaller exponent from the larger one, keeping the same base.
If the larger exponent occurs in the numerator, put the power in the numerator. \text{If }m\gt n,~\text{ then }~ \frac{a^m}{a^n}=a^{m-n} \hphantom{blank}(a \ne 0)
If the larger exponent occurs in the denominator, put the power in the denominator. \text{If }m\lt n,~\text{ then }~ \frac{a^m}{a^n}=\frac{1}{a^{n-m}} \hphantom{blank}(a \ne 0)

example.p: Divide \dfrac{3x^2 y^4}{6x^3 y}.

subsection.title: Power of a Power

assemblage.title: Third Law of Exponents: Power of a Power
assemblage.p: To raise a power to a power, keep the same base and multiply the exponents. \left(a^m\right)^n = a^{mn}

image.description: examples of raising a power to a power by multiplying exponents

warning.p:
Notice the difference between the expressions (x^3) (x^4) = x^{3+4} = x^7 and \left(x^3\right)^4 = x^{3\, \cdot \, 4} = x^{12}
The first expression is a product, so we add the exponents. The second expression raises a power to a power, so we multiply the exponents.

subsection.title: Power of a Product
subsection.p:
To simplify the expression (5a)^3, we use the associative and commutative laws to regroup the factors as follows.
(5a)^3 \amp = (5a) (5a) (5a)
\amp = 5 \cdot 5 \cdot 5 \cdot a \cdot a \cdot a
\amp = 5^3 a^3
Thus, to raise a product to a power, we can simply raise each factor to the power.

assemblage.title: Fourth Law of Exponents: Power of a Product
assemblage.p: A power of a product is equal to the product of the powers of each of its factors. (ab)^n = a^n b^n

li.p: (5a)^3 = 5^3a^3 = 125a^3\hphantom{blank}\text{Cube each factor}.

Compare the two expressions 3a^2 and (3a)^2; they are not the same. In the expression 3a^2, only the factor a is squared. But in (3a)^2, both 3 and a are squared. Thus, 3a^2 ~~\text{ cannot be simplified} but (3a)^2 = 3^2a^2 = 9a^2

Compare the two expressions (3a)^2 and (3 + a)^2. The fourth law of exponents applies to the product 3a, but not to the sum 3+a. Thus, (3 + a)^2 \ne 3^2 + a^2 In order to simplify (3 + a)^2, we must expand the binomial product: (3 + a)^2 = (3 + a) (3 + a) = 9 + 6a + a^2

subsection.title: Power of a Quotient

assemblage.title: Fifth Law of Exponents: Power of a Quotient
assemblage.p: To raise a quotient to a power, raise both the numerator and denominator to the power. \left(\frac{a}{b}\right)^n=\frac{a^n}{b^n}

subsection.p: For reference, we state all of the laws of exponents together. All the laws are valid when a and b are not equal to zero and when the exponents m and n are whole numbers.

introduction.p: In , we used the first law of exponents to multiply two or more monomials. In this section, we review techniques for multiplying and factoring polynomials of several terms.

subsection.title: Polynomials
subsection.p: A polynomialpolynomial is a sum of terms in which all the exponents on the variables are whole numbers and no variables appear in the denominator or under a radical. The expressions 0.1 R^4, ~~d^2 + 32 d - 21, ~~\text{ and }~~128x^3 - 960x^2 + 8000 are all examples of polynomials in one variable.

An algebraic expression consisting of one term of the form cx^n, where c is a constant and n is a whole number, is called a monomialmonomial. For example, y3, ~~-3x^8, ~~\text{ and } ~~0.1R^4 are monomials. A polynomial is just a sum of one or more monomials.

A polynomial with exactly two terms, such as \dfrac{1}{2}n^2 + \dfrac{1}{2}n, is called a binomialbinomial. A polynomial with exactly three terms, such as d^2 + 32 d - 21 or 128x^3 - 960x^2 + 8000, is called a trinomialtrinomial. We have no special names for polynomials with more than three terms.

solution.p: The first three are all polynomials. In fact, (a) is a monomial, (b) is a binomial, and (c) is a trinomial. The last three are not polynomials. The variable in (d) has a negative exponent, the variable in (e) occurs in the denominator, and the variable in (f) occurs under a radical.

subsection.p: In a polynomial containing only one variable, the greatest exponent that appears on the variable is called the degreedegree of the polynomial. If there is no variable at all, then the polynomial is called a constant, and the degree of a constant is zero.

example.p:
Give the degree of each polynomial.
b^3 - 3b^2 + 3b - 1
10^{10}
-4w^3
s^2 - s^6

li.p: This is a polynomial in the variable b, and because the greatest exponent on b is 3, the degree of this polynomial is 3.
This is a constant polynomial, so its degree is 0. (The exponent on a constant does not affect the degree.)
This monomial has degree 3.
This is a binomial of degree 6.

subsection.p: We can evaluate a polynomial just as we evaluate any other algebraic expression: We replace the variable with a number and simplify the result.

example.p:
Let p(x) = -2x^2 + 3x - 1. Evaluate each of the following.
p(2)
p(-1)
p(t)
p(t+3)

solution.p:
In each case, we replace x by the given value.
p(\alert{2})=-2(\alert{2})^2 + 3(\alert{2}) - 1=-8+6-1=-3
p(\alert{-1})=-2(\alert{-1})^2 + 3(\alert{-1}) - 1=-2+(-3)-1=-6
p(\alert{t})=-2(\alert{t})^2 + 3(\alert{t}) - 1=--2t^2+3t-1
\begin{aligned} \amp \\ p(\alert{t+3})\amp =-2(\alert{t+3})^2 + 3(\alert{t+3}) - 1\\ \amp = -2(t^2+6t+9)+3(t+3)-1\\ \amp = -2t^2-9t-10 \end{aligned}

subsection.title: Products of Polynomials
subsection.p: To multiply polynomials, we use a generalized form of the distributive property: a(b + c + d + \cdots) = ab + ac + ad + \cdots To multiply a polynomial by a monomial, we multiply each term of the polynomial by the monomial.

subsection.title: Products of Binomials
subsection.p: Products of binomials occur so frequently that it is worthwhile to learn a shortcut for this type of multiplication. We can use the following scheme to perform the multiplication mentally. (See .)

subsection.title: Factoring
subsection.p: We sometimes find it useful to write a polynomial as a single term composed of two or more factors. This process is the reverse of multiplication and is called factoringfactoring. For example, observe that 3x^2 + 6x = 3x(x + 2) We will only consider factorization in which the factors have integer coefficients.

subsection.title: Common Factors
subsection.p: We can factor a common factor from a polynomial by using the distributive property in the form ab + ac = a(b + c) We first identify the common factor. For example, each term of the polynomial 6x^3 + 9x^2 - 3x contains the monomial 3x as a factor; therefore, 6x^3 + 9x^2 - 3x = 3x () Next, we insert the proper polynomial factor within the parentheses. This factor can be determined by inspection. We ask ourselves for monomials that, when multiplied by 3x, yield 6x^3, 9x^2, and -3x, respectively, and obtain 6x^3 + 9x^2 - 3x = 3x(2x^2 + 3x - 1)
We can check the result of factoring an expression by multiplying the factors. In the example above, 3x(2x^2 + 3x - 1) = 6x^3 + 9x^2 - 3x

subsection.title: Opposite of a Binomial
subsection.p:
It is often useful to factor -1 from the terms of a binomial.
a - b \amp = (-1)(-a + b)
\amp = (-1)(b - a) = -(b - a)
Hence, we have the following important relationship.
That is, a-b and b-a are opposites or negatives of each other.

subsection.title: Polynomial Division
subsection.p: We can divide one polynomial by a polynomial of lesser degree. The quotient will be the sum of a polynomial and a simpler algebraic fraction.
If the divisor is a monomial, we can simply divide the monomial into each term of the numerator.

example.p: Divide \dfrac{9x^3 - 6x^2 + 4}{3x}

subsection.p: If the denominator is not a monomial, we can use a method similar to the long division algorithm used in arithmetic.

introduction.p:
Consider the trinomial
x^2 + 10x + 16
Can we find two binomial factors, (x + a)(x + b) whose product is the given trinomial? The product of the binomials is (x + a)(x + b) = x^2 + (a + b)x + ab Thus, we are looking for two numbers, a and b, that satisfy (x + a)(x + b) = x^2 + (a + b)x + ab (x + a)(x + b) = x^2 + (a + b)x + ab= x^2 + 10x + 16 By comparing the coefficients of the terms in the two trinomials, we see that a + b = 10 and ab = 16. That is, the sum of the two numbers is the coefficient of the linear term, 10, and their product is the constant term, 16.

To find the numbers, we list all the possible integer factorizations of 16: 1 \cdot 16, ~~~2 \cdot 8, ~~~\text{ and }~~~ 4 \cdot 4 We see that only one combination gives the correct linear term: 8 and 2. These are the numbers a and b, so x^2 + 10x + 16 = (x + 8)(x + 2)
In we factor quadratic trinomials in which one or more of the coefficients is negative.

example.p:
Factor.
x^2-7x+12
x^2-x-12

li.p: Find two numbers whose product is 12 and whose sum is -7. Because the product is positive and the sum is negative, the two numbers must both be negative. The possible factors of 12 are -1 and -12, -2 and -6, or -3 and -4. Only -4 and -3 have the correct sum, -7. Hence, x^2 - 7x + 12 = (x - 4) (x - 3)

Find two numbers whose product is -12 and whose sum is -1. Because the product is negative, the two numbers must be of opposite sign and their sum must be -1. By listing the possible factors of -12, we find that the two numbers are -4 and 3. Hence, x^2 - x - 12 = (x - 4) (x + 3)

introduction.p: If the coefficient of the quadratic term is not 1, we must also consider its factors.

example.p: Factor 8x^2 - 9 - 21x.

List the possible factors for the quadratic term.
(8x\hphantom{00000})\amp(x\hphantom{000000}) (4x\hphantom{00000})\amp(2x\hphantom{00000})

Consider possible factors for the constant term: 9 may be factored as 9\cdot 1 or as 3\cdot 3. Form all possible pairs of binomial factor using these factorizations. (See .) list of possible binomial factor pairs
Select the combinations of the products ❶ and ❷ whose sum or difference could be the linear term, -21x. (8x \hphantom{000} 3) (x \hphantom{000} 3)
Insert the proper signs: (8x + 3) (x - 3)

introduction.p:
With practice, you can usually factor trinomials of the form Ax^2 + Bx + C mentally. The following observations may help.
If A, B and C are all positive, both signs in the factored form are positive. For example, as a first step in factoring 6x^2 + 11x + 4, we could write (\hphantom{000} + \hphantom{000} ) (\hphantom{000} + \hphantom{000} )
If A and C are positive and B is negative, both signs in the factored form are negative. Thus as a first step in factoring 6x^2 - 11x + 4, we could write (\hphantom{000} - \hphantom{000} ) (\hphantom{000} - \hphantom{000} )
If C is negative, the signs in the factored form are opposite. Thus as a first step in factoring 6x^2 - 5x - 4, we could write (\hphantom{000} + \hphantom{000} ) (\hphantom{000} - \hphantom{000} ) ~~\text{ or }~~ (\hphantom{000} - \hphantom{000} ) (\hphantom{000} + \hphantom{000} )

subsection.title: Special Products and Factors
subsection.p: The products below are special cases of the multiplication of binomials. They occur so often that you should learn to recognize them on sight.

Notice that in (I) (a + b)^2

(x + 4)^2 \amp

subsection.p: Each of the formulas for special products, when viewed from right to left, also represents a special case of factoring quadratic polynomials.

The trinomials in (I) and (II) are sometimes called perfect-square trinomialsperfect-square trinomials because they are squares of binomials. Note that the sum of two squares, a^2 + b^2, cannot be factored.

li.p:
Because 16 is equal to 4^2 and 8 is equal to 2\cdot 4,
x^2 + 8x + 16 \amp = x^2 - 2 \cdot 4x + 4^2 \amp = (x + 4)^2

Because 25=5^2 and 10=2\cdot 5,
y^2 - 10y + 25 \amp = y^2 - 2 \cdot 5y + 5^2 \amp = (y-5)^2

subsection.p: Binomials of the form a^2 - b^2 are often called the difference of two squaresdifference of two squares.

example.p:
Factor if possible.
x^2 - 81
4x^2 - 9y^2
x^2 + 81

li.p:
The expression x^2 - 81 is the difference of two squares, x^2 - 9^2, and thus can be factored according to Special Factorization (III) above.
x^2-81 \amp = x^2-9^2 \amp = (x+9)(x-9)

Because 4x^2 - 9y^2 can be written as (2x)^2 -(3y)^2,
4x^2 - 9y^2 \amp =(2x^2)-(3y)^2 \amp =(2x+3y)(2x-3y)

warning.p: x^2 + 81\ne (x + 9) (x + 9), which you can verify by multiplying (x + 9) (x + 9) = x^2 + 18x + 8

subsection.p: The factors x + 9 and x - 9 in a are called conjugatesconjugates of each other. In general, any binomials of the form a+b and a-b are called a conjugate pairconjugate pair.

introduction.p: A quotient of two polynomials is called a rational expressionrational expression or an algebraic fractionalgebraic fraction. Operations on algebraic fractions follow the same rules as operations on common fractions.

subsection.title: Reducing Fractions
subsection.p: When we reduce an ordinary fraction such as \dfrac{24}{36}, we are using the fundamental principle of fractions.

assemblage.title: Fundamental Principle of Fractions
assemblage.p: If we multiply or divide the numerator and denominator of a fraction by the same (nonzero) number, the new fraction is equivalent to the old one. In symbols, \frac{ac}{bc}=\frac{a}{b}, \hphantom{0000} (b, ~c \ne 0)

subsection.p: Thus, for example, \frac{24}{36}=\frac{2\cdot 12}{3\cdot 12}=\frac{2}{3}
We use the same procedure to reduce algebraic fractions: We look for common factors in the numerator and denominator and then apply the fundamental principle.

If the numerator or denominator of the fraction contains more than one term, it is especially important to factor before attempting to apply the fundamental principle. We can divide out common factors from the numerator and denominator of a fraction, but the fundamental principle does not apply to common terms.

warning.p: Note that in a above, \frac{4x + 2}{4} \ne x+2 and in b, \frac{9x^2+3}{6x+3} \ne \frac{9x^2}{6x}

subsection.p: We summarize the procedure for reducing algebraic fractions as follows.

li.p: Factor the numerator and denominator.
Divide the numerator and denominator by any common factors.

The numerator of the fraction is a difference of two cubes, and the denominator is a difference of two squares. Factor each to obtain \frac{\cancel{(3x-1)}(9x^2+3x+1)}{\cancel{(3x-1)}(3x+1)}=\frac{9x^2+3x+1}{3x+1}

subsection.title: Products of Fractions
subsection.p:
To multiply two or more common fractions together, we multiply their numerators together and multiply their denominators together. The same is true for a product of algebraic fractions. For example, xy
\frac{6x^2}{y}\cdot\frac{xy}{2}\amp =\frac{6x^2\cdot}{y\cdot 2}=\frac{6x^3y}{2y}\amp\amp\text{Reduce.} \amp =\frac{3x^3(2y)}{2y}=3x^3
We can simplify the process by first factoring each numerator and denominator and dividing out any common factors. \frac{6x^2}{y}\cdot\frac{\cancel{2}\cdot 3x^2}{\bcancel{y}}\cdot\frac{x\bcancel{y}}{\cancel{2}}=3x^3
In general, we have the following procedure for finding the product of algebraic fractions.

li.p: Factor each numerator and denominator.
Divide out any factors that appear in both a numerator and a denominator.
Multiply together the numerators; multiply together the denominators.

The denominator of the first fraction factors into (x + 1) (x - 1). There are no common factors to divide out, so we multiply the numerators together and multiply the denominators together. \frac{5}{x^2-1}\cdot\frac{x+2}{x}=\frac{5(x+2)}{x(x^2-1)}=\frac{5x+10}{x^3-x}

subsection.title: Quotients of Fractions
subsection.p: If the fractions involve polynomials of more than one term, we may need to factor each numerator and denominator in order to recognize any common factors. This suggests the following procedure for dividing algebraic fractions.

li.p: Multiply the first fraction by the reciprocal of the second fraction.
Factor each numerator and denominator.
Divide out any factors that appear in both a numerator and a denominator.
Multiply together the numerators; multiply together the denominators.

subsection.title: Sums and Differences of Like Fractions
subsection.p: Algebraic fractions with the same denominator are called like fractionslike fractions. To add or subtract like fractions, we combine their numerators and keep the same denominator for the sum or difference. This method is an application of the distributive law.

li.p:
Because these are like fractions, we add their numerators and keep the same denominator.
\frac{2x}{9z^2}+\frac{5x}{9z^2}=\frac{2x+5x}{9z^2}=\frac{7x}{9z^2}

subsection.title: Lowest Common Denominator
subsection.p: To add or subtract fractions with different denominators, we must first find a common denominatorcommon denominator. For arithmetic fractions, we use the smallest natural number that is exactly divisible by each of the given denominators. For example, to add the fractions \dfrac{1}{6} and \dfrac{3}{8}, we use 24 as the common denominator because 24 is the smallest natural number that both 6 and 8 divide into evenly.

We define the lowest common denominatorlowest common denominator (LCDLCD) of two or more algebraic fractions as the polynomial of least degree that is exactly divisible by each of the given denominators.

example.p: Find the LCD for the fractions \dfrac{3x}{x+2} and \dfrac{2x}{x-3}

solution.p: The LCD is a polynomial that has as factors both x + 2 and x-3. The simplest such polynomial is (x + 2) (x - 3), or x^2 - x - 6. For our purposes, it will be more convenient to leave the LCD in factored form, so the LCD is (x + 2) (x - 3).

subsection.p: The LCD in was easy to find because each original denominator consisted of a single factor; that is, neither denominator could be factored. In that case, the LCD is just the product of the original denominators. We can always find a common denominator by multiplying together all the denominators in the given fractions, but this may not give us the simplest or lowest common denominator. Using anything other than the simplest possible common denominator will complicate our work needlessly.
If any of the denominators in the given fractions can be factored, we factor them before looking for the LCD.

assemblage.title: To Find the LCD of Algebraic Fractions:

li.p: Factor each denominator completely.
Include each different factor in the LCD as many times as it occurs in any one of the given denominators.

example.p: Find the LCD for the fractions \dfrac{2x}{x^2-1} and \dfrac{x+3}{x^2+x}.

solution.p: Factor the denominators of each of the given fractions. x^2 - 1 = (x - 1) (x + 1)~~~\text{ and }~~~x^2 + x = x (x + 1) The factor (x - 1) occurs once in the first denominator, the factor x occurs once in the second denominator, and the factor (x + 1) occurs once in each denominator. Therefore, we include in our LCD one copy of each of these factors. The LCD is x (x + 1) (x - 1).

warning.p: In , we do not include two factors of (x + 1) in the LCD. We need only one factor of (x + 1) because (x + 1) occurs only once in either denominator. You should check that each original denominator divides evenly into our LCD, x (x + 1)(x - 1).

subsection.title: Building Fractions
subsection.p: After finding the LCD, we buildbuild each fraction to an equivalent one with the LCD as its denominator. The new fractions will be like fractions, and we can combine them as explained above.

Building a fraction is the opposite of reducing a fraction, in the sense that we multiply, rather than divide, the numerator and denominator by an appropriate factor. To find the building factorbuilding factor, we compare the factors of the original denominator with those of the desired common denominator.

example.p: Build each of the fractions \dfrac{3x}{x+2} and \dfrac{2x}{x-3} to equivalent fractions with the LCD (x + 2)(x - 3) as denominator.

subsection.p: The two new fractions we obtained in are like fractions; they have the same denominator.

subsection.title: Sums and Differences of Unlike Fractions
subsection.p: We are now ready to add or subtract algebraic fractions with unlike denominators. We will do this in four steps.

assemblage.title: To Add or Subtract Fractions with Unlike Denominators:

li.p: Find the LCD for the given fractions.
Build each fraction to an equivalent fraction with the LCD as its denominator.
Add or subtract the numerators of the resulting like fractions. Use the LCD as the denominator of the sum or difference.
Reduce the sum or difference, if possible.

example.p: Subtract \dfrac{3x}{x+2}-\dfrac{2x}{x-3} .

li.p: The LCD for these fractions is (x + 2) (x - 3).

We build each fraction to an equivalent one with the LCD, as we did in .
\frac{3x}{x+2}=\frac{3x^2-9x}{x^2-x-6} ~~\text{ and }~~ \frac{2x}{x-3}=\frac{2x^2+4x}{x^2-x-6}

example.p: Write as a single fraction: \displaystyle{1 + \frac{2}{a}-\frac{a^2 + 2}{a^2 + a}}.

To find the LCD, factor each denominator:
a\amp =a a^2 + a\amp = a (a + 1)

subsection.title: Complex Fractions
subsection.p: If the numerator or denominator of the complex fraction contains more than one term, it is easier to use the fundamental principle of fractions to simplify the expression.

example.p: Simplify \displaystyle{\frac{x+\dfrac{3}{4}}{x-\dfrac{1}{2}} }

subsection.p: We summarize the method for simplifying complex fractions as follows.

li.p: Find the LCD of all the fractions contained in the complex fraction.
Multiply each term in the numerator and the denominator of the complex fraction by the LCD.
Reduce the resulting simple fraction, if possible.

subsection.title: Negative Exponents
subsection.p: Algebraic fractions are sometimes written using negative exponents. (You can review negative exponents in .)
When working with fractions and exponents, it is important to avoid some tempting but incorrect algebraic operations.

li.p: In a, note that \frac{1}{x}-\frac{1}{y}\ne\frac{1}{x-y} For example, you can check that for x=2 and y=3, \frac{1}{2}-\frac{1}{3}\ne\frac{1}{2-3}=-1
In b, note that \left(x^{-2}+y^{-2}\right)^{-1}\ne x^2+y^2

subsection.p: In general, the fourth law of exponents does not apply to sums and differences; that is, (a+b)^n\ne a^n + b^n

introduction.p: In some situations, radical notation is more convenient to use than exponents. In these cases, we usually simplify radical expressions algebraically as much as possible before using a calculator to obtain decimal approximations.

subsection.title: Properties of Radicals
subsection.p: Because \sqrt[n]{a}=a^{1/n}, we can use the laws of exponents to derive two important properties that are useful in simplifying radicals.

As examples, you can verify that
\sqrt{36}=\sqrt{4}\sqrt{9} ~~~\text{ and }~~~ \sqrt[3]{\frac{1}{8}}=\frac{\sqrt[3]{1}}{\sqrt[3]{8}}

solution.p: The statements in (b) and (d) are true, and both are examples of the first property of radicals. Statements (a) and (c) are false. In general, \sqrt[n]{a+b} is not equal to \sqrt[n]{a}+\sqrt[n]{b}, and \sqrt[n]{a-b} is not equal to \sqrt[n]{a}-\sqrt[n]{b}.

subsection.title: Simplifying Radicals
subsection.p: To simplify roots of fractions, we use Property (2), which allows us to write the expression as a quotient of two radicals.
We can also use Properties (1) and (2) to simplify products and quotients of radicals.

subsection.title: Sums and Differences of Radicals
subsection.p:
You know that sums or differences of like terms can be combined by adding or subtracting their coefficients:
3xy + 5xy = (3 + 5)xy = 8xy
Like radicals, that is, radicals of the same index and radicand, can be combined in the same way.

li.p: In a, 3\sqrt{3}+4\sqrt{3}\ne 7\sqrt{6} . Only the coefficients are added; the radicand does not change.

subsection.title: Products of Radicals
subsection.p: According to Property (1), radicals of the same index can be multiplied together.

Thus, for example,
\sqrt{2}\sqrt{18}\sqrt{36}=6 ~~~\text{ and }~~~\sqrt[3]{2x}\sqrt[3]{4x^2}=\sqrt[3]{8x^3}=2x
For products involving binomials, we can apply the distributive law.

subsection.title: Rationalizing the Denominator
subsection.p: It is easier to work with radicals if there are no roots in the denominators of fractions. We can use the fundamental principle of fractions to remove radicals from the denominator. This process is called rationalizing the denominatorrationalizing the denominator. For square roots, we multiply the numerator and denominator of the fraction by the radical in the denominator.

If the denominator of a fraction is a binomial in which one or both terms is a radical, we can use a special building factor to rationalize it. First, recall that (p - q) (p + q) = p^2 - q^2 where the product consists of perfect squares only. Each of the two factors p - q and p + q is said to be the conjugateconjugate of the other.

example.p: Rationalize the denominator: \displaystyle{\frac{x}{\sqrt{2}+\sqrt{x}}} .

subsection.title: Simplifying \sqrt[n]{x^n}
subsection.p:
Raising to a power is the inverse operation for extracting roots; that is, \boxed{\hphantom{0000} \left(\sqrt[n]{a} \right)^n =a \hphantom{0000}} as long as \sqrt[n]{a} is a real number. For example,
\left(\sqrt[4]{16} \right)^4= 2^4 = 16,~~~\text{ and }~~~\left(\sqrt[3]{-125} \right)^3= (-5)^3 = -125

Now consider the power and root operations in the opposite order; is it true that \sqrt[n]{a^n}=a ? If the index n is an odd number, then the statement is always true. For example,
\sqrt[3]{2^3}=\sqrt[3]{8}=2 ~~~\text{ and }~~~\sqrt[3]{(-2)^3}=\sqrt[3]{-8}=-2
However, if n is even, we must be careful. Recall that the principal root \sqrt[n]{x} is always positive, so if a is a negative number, it cannot be true that \sqrt[n]{a^n}=a . For example, if a = -3, then
\sqrt{(-3)^2}=\sqrt{9}=3
Instead, we see that, for even roots, \sqrt[n]{a^n}=\abs{a} .
We summarize our results in below.

li.p: If n is odd, \hphantom{blankblank}\sqrt[n]{a^n}=a
If n is even, \hphantom{blankblank}\sqrt[n]{a^n}=\abs{a}
In particular, \hphantom{blankblank}\sqrt{a^2}=\abs{a}

subsection.title: Extraneous Solutions to Radical Equations
subsection.p:
It is important to check the solution to a radical equation, because it is possible to introduce false, or extraneousextraneous, solutions when we square both sides of the equation. For example, the equation \sqrt{x}=-5 has no solution, because \sqrt{x} is never a negative number. However, if we try to solve the equation by squaring both sides, we find
(\sqrt{x})^\alert{2}\amp = (-5)^\alert{2}
x\amp = 25
You can check that 25 is not a solution to the original equation, \sqrt{x}=-5 , because \sqrt{25} does not equal -5.

If each side of an equation is raised to an odd power, extraneous solutions will not be introduced. However, if we raise both sides to an even power, we should check each solution in the original equation.

example.p: Solve the equation \sqrt{x+2}+4=x .

solution.p: The apparent solution 2 is extraneous. The only solution to the original equation is 7. We can verify the solution by graphing the equations y_1=\sqrt{x+2} ~~~\text{ and }~~~ y_2=x-4 as shown in . The graphs intersect in only one point, (7, 3), so there is only one solution, x=7.

image.description: graphs of both sides of radical equation

warning.p: When we square both sides of an equation, it is not correct to square each term of the equation separately. Thus, in , the original equation is not equivalent to (\sqrt{x+2})^2+4^2=x^2 This is because (a + b)^2 \ne a^2 + b^2. Instead, we must square the entire left side of the equation as a binomial, like this, (\sqrt{x+2}+4)^2=x^2 or we may proceed as shown in .

subsection.title: Equations with More than One Radical
subsection.p: Sometimes it is necessary to square both sides of an equation more than once in order to eliminate all the radicals.

example.p: Solve \sqrt{x-7}+\sqrt{x}=7 .

warning.p: Recall that we cannot solve a radical equation by squaring each term separately. In other words, it is incorrect to begin by writing (\sqrt{x-7})^2+(\sqrt{x})^2=7^2 We must square the entire expression on each side of the equal sign as one piece.
